title: Here We Go Again: Tax Extenders Bill Countdown Begins
text:
It’s Christmas in July!
In recent years, taxpayers have been forced to wait until the end of the year before Congress pushed through a tax extenders bill – which totally makes sense, right? Why would you want to provide taxpayers with any sense of how to plan before the year actually ends? Crazy talk, I know.
But this year, crazy must be on the agenda because it’s just midyear and the Senate is already making noise about a tax extender package. By comparison, in 2014 , the Senate waited until just over two weeks left in the calendar year to pass a bill that extended certain tax provisions through December 31, 2014 (retroactive to January 1, 2014). At the time, Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-UT) referred to the bill as “quite literally the best we could do.”
Sen. Hatch is clearly hoping to do a little better this time, announcing , together with Sen. Ron Wyden (D-OR), that the Senate Finance Committee will begin markup on a tax extenders bill on Tuesday, July 21.
Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, center, leaves a policy luncheon at the U.S. Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, June 23, 2015. The Senate pushed bipartisan trade legislation to the brink of final approval Tuesday in a combined effort by President Barack Obama and Republican congressional leaders to rescue a measure that appeared all but dead less than two weeks ago. (AP Photo/Cliff Owen)
Sen. Hatch said, about the (cough) head start, “This markup will give the committee a timely opportunity to act on extending a number of expired provisions in the tax code that help families, individuals and small businesses.” He went on to note that “we need to advance a package as soon as possible. This package is a result of strong bipartisan work, and I look forward to working with the full committee to ensure members are able to work their will and examine these provisions carefully.
His colleague, Sen. Wyden, agreed saying, “We need to extend these tax provisions now in order to provide greater certainty and predictability for middle class families and businesses alike.”
It all sounds really great, right?
